thread.title: EKU FOOTBALL: Thomas makes most of opportunity
thread.title_full: EKU FOOTBALL: Thomas makes most of opportunity

author: Nathan Hutchinson, Register Sports Editor
title: EKU FOOTBALL: Thomas makes most of opportunity
text:
By Nathan Hutchinson, Register Sports Editor 10.1 thomas eku 
EKU freshan Ethan Thomas picks up yards last week in a win over Austin Peay Posted: Wednesday, September 30, 2015 11:49 pm EKU FOOTBALL: Thomas makes most of opportunity Nathan Hutchinson, Register Sports Editor Richmond Register 
The EKU coaching staff normally prefers to redshirt all incoming freshman. 
But, the first time they saw Ethan Thomas, they knew it would be hard to keep him off the field this season. 
“We felt like physically, he was ready to play a college football game,” EKU coach Dean Hood said. “When he came on his visit, he didn’t look like most high school kids.” 
The 5-foot-11, 210-pound freshman from Johnson City, Tenn., has gotten an opportunity to play — and he has been very impressive. 
Through the first three games of the season, Thomas has a team-best three touchdowns and is also among the team leaders in rushing yards (65 — third) and rush attempts (14 — third). 
The freshman also has four receptions for 31 yards. 
Last week in a blowout win over Austin Peay in the OVC opener, Thomas had 12 carries for 59 yards and two touchdowns (runs of 8 and 9 yards) 
“We thought for sure he would be a kid we would redshirt, especially after we got (Florida transfer) Adam (Lane),” Hood said of Thomas. “The injuries we’ve had, we’ve had to push him to play and he’s been everything that we thought he was and more.” 
Injuries have certainly have helped Thomas move up the depth chart. 
Dy’Shawn Mobley, last year’s OVC Offensive Player of the Year, has been slowed by a hamstring injury since prior to training camp. Lane also has battled a nagging hamstring problem. 
And last Saturday, Kentayvus Hopkins left the game in the first half with a knee injury. 
Thomas was three-time all-state performer for Elizabethtown High School and finished with more than 6,400 career yards. He was the MVP of the Tennessee East-West All-Star Game and he ranks in the Top 10 all-time among Tennessee high school players in several categories — rushing yards (ninth), rushing touchdowns (77, ninth), career touchdowns (79, 10th), consecutive 100-yard rushing games (17, fourth) and 100-yard rushing games (35, second). 
Kicking it up 
The Colonels came into training camp with three kickers competing for playing time. 
And through three games, all of them have been able to make contributions in different roles. 
Sophomore Lucas Williams emerged as the starting placekicker and has been perfect so far. The Russell Springs native has hit all four of his field goal attempts and is 12-for-12 on extra point attempts. 
Williams hit three fields last week against Austin Peay — 28, 37 and 42 yards. 
Ben Deighton and Zack Burgy-Vanhoose have split the kickoff duties. 
Deighton has eight touchbacks on 11 kicks for an average of 64.5 Vanhoose has kicked off nine times and has an average of 60.1 yards.
